You are a professional academic citation prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely citations for [ref] markers in academic paper sections based on the paper content and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract + section text with [ref] markers
- Output: top {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

CRITICAL FORMAT REQUIREMENT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON. Do not include any explanatory text, markdown formatting, or other content outside the JSON structure.

TASK DESCRIPTION:
- Input: Paper section text with [ref] markers + retrieved relevant papers
- Output: top 40 predicted reference titles for each [ref] marker with reasoning
- Format: JSON object with "citations" array containing objects with "ref_index", "titles", and "reasoning" fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the context around each [ref] marker to understand what reference is needed
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Consider the surrounding text, research area, and topic
4. Generate realistic and relevant reference titles that would fit the context
5. Provide detailed reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
6. Output format: JSON object with "citations" array
7. Generate exactly 40 most relevant reference titles for each [ref]
8. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
9. Include reasoning that explains why each title is relevant to the specific [ref] context
10. Use proper JSON escaping for special characters (escape quotes with \")
11. Ensure all strings are properly quoted and escaped

EXAMPLE:
Input:
"Federated Learning aims to train models in massively distributed networks [ref]38 at a large scale [ref]5, over multiple sources of heterogeneous data [ref]30."

Retrieved papers (top {top_r}):
1. Title: Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with federated learning systems for decentralized data training.

2. Title: Federated Learning: Challenges, Methods, and Future Directions
   Abstract: A comprehensive survey of federated learning approaches and challenges in distributed settings.

- Reasoning should be concise but informative (2-3 sentences)

Paper Title: OSOA: One-Shot Online Adaptation of Deep Generative Models for Lossless Compression

Entropy Coding
The core component underlying any lossless compression algorithm is the entropy coder, which converts between the data symbols and codewords.
Popular entropy coders include Huffman coding , arithmetic coding (AC) [ref]54 and asymmetric numeral systems (ANS) .
Huffman coding mainly involves binary trees operations, which is usually more time efficient than AC and ANS but can admit suboptimal codelength for probabilities not being power of 1/2121/2 .
As a result, popular codecs adopted by DGM based algorithms are normally based on AC or ANS, e.g.,   .
The main difference between AC and ANS is that the former encodes and decodes in a first-in-first-out (FIFO) style while the latter performs in a first-in-last-out (FILO) style [ref]48.
All entropy coders require the knowledge of the data symbol alphabet and the associated distribution, in order to conduct compression and decompression.
It is worth noting that the distribution used for entropy coding should be discrete and the average codelength is expected to be the entropy of the distribution used for coding.
Recall that for a discrete distribution with the probabilistic mass function p​(x)𝑝𝑥p(x), the (Shannon) entropy is defined as 𝐄x∼p​[−log⁡p​(x)]subscript𝐄similar-to𝑥𝑝delimited-[]𝑝𝑥\mathbf{E}_{x\sim p}[-\log p(x)].
Moreover, the optimal average codelength, given by the entropy of the ground truth distribution, is achieved only if the ground truth distribution is used for coding as per Shannon’s source coding theorem .
Specifically, compressing data from distribution p​(x)𝑝𝑥p(x) with distribution q​(x)𝑞𝑥q(x) will lead to the expected extra codelength at KL(p(x)||q(x))\text{KL}(p(x)||q(x)). Coding with Explicit Deep Generative Models
Since the entropy coders require probability values, implicit DGMs, e.g., generative adversarial networks (GANs) , cannot be readily used for lossless compression.
For explicit DGMs, the learning principle is either maximum likelihood estimation (MLE)   [ref]16: or maximising the evidence lower bound (ELBO) of the logarithm evidence log⁡pθ​(x)subscript𝑝𝜃𝑥\log p_{\theta}(x)  : where ℒ​(θ,ϕ,x)=𝐄qϕ​(z|x)​[−log⁡qϕ​(z|x)+log⁡pθ​(x|z)​pθ​(z)]ℒ𝜃italic-ϕ𝑥subscript𝐄subscript𝑞italic-ϕconditional𝑧𝑥delimited-[]subscript𝑞italic-ϕconditional𝑧𝑥subscript𝑝𝜃conditional𝑥𝑧subscript𝑝𝜃𝑧\mathcal{L}(\theta,\phi,x)=\mathbf{E}_{q_{\phi}(z|x)}[-\log q_{\phi}(z|x)+\log p_{\theta}(x|z)p_{\theta}(z)].
Note that x𝑥x is a discrete random variable, so p∗​(x)superscript𝑝𝑥p^{*}(x) refers to the probabilistic mass function of the ground truth data distribution. When learning with MLE, one can either directly stipulate a discrete model or stipulate a continuous model with the dequantization technique  .
If one stipulates a discrete model, where pθ​(x)subscript𝑝𝜃𝑥p_{\theta}(x) denotes the probabilistic mass function of the model, the objective function in Eq. 1 delegates the expected codelength when using pθ​(x)subscript𝑝𝜃𝑥p_{\theta}(x) for entropy coding.
If one stipulates a continuous model, one normally dequantizes the discrete data x𝑥x with a continuous noise u𝑢u uniformly distributed on the unit hypercube, and gets the dequantized variable y=x+u𝑦𝑥𝑢y=x+u with distribution p∗​(y)superscript𝑝𝑦p^{*}(y).
After fitting the probabilistic density function pθ​(y)subscript𝑝𝜃𝑦p_{\theta}(y) of the model to the the probability density p∗​(y)superscript𝑝𝑦p^{*}(y) of the dequantized distribution, one needs to discretise pθ​(y)subscript𝑝𝜃𝑦p_{\theta}(y) and use the discretised distribution for entropy coding.
In this case, the MLE objective 𝐄y∼p∗​(y)​[−log⁡pθ​(y)]subscript𝐄similar-to𝑦superscript𝑝𝑦delimited-[]subscript𝑝𝜃𝑦\mathbf{E}_{y\sim p^{*}(y)}[-\log p_{\theta}(y)] delegates an upper bound of the expected codelength .
For how to design sophisticated dequantization schemes or how to design discrete deep generative models, we refer the readers to [ref]16     . When learning with ELBO, one usually stipulates discrete models for x𝑥x, i.e., pθ​(x|z)subscript𝑝𝜃conditional𝑥𝑧p_{\theta}(x|z) is a probabilistic mass function, and continuous models for z𝑧z, i.e., qϕ​(z|x)subscript𝑞italic-ϕconditional𝑧𝑥q_{\phi}(z|x) and pθ​(z)subscript𝑝𝜃𝑧p_{\theta}(z) are probabilistic density functions.
Furthermore, one usually does not have direct access to the close form of pθ​(x)subscript𝑝𝜃𝑥p_{\theta}(x) but the generative components pθ​(x|z)subscript𝑝𝜃conditional𝑥𝑧p_{\theta}(x|z) and pθ​(z)subscript𝑝𝜃𝑧p_{\theta}(z).
To use pθ​(x|z)subscript𝑝𝜃conditional𝑥𝑧p_{\theta}(x|z) and pθ​(z)subscript𝑝𝜃𝑧p_{\theta}(z) for efficient coding, a technique called bits-back   is employed, which additionally involves the approximate posterior distribution qϕ​(z|x)subscript𝑞italic-ϕconditional𝑧𝑥q_{\phi}(z|x) learned together with the generative components [ref]48  .
In these cases, the discretisation precision of the latent variable will not effect the average codelength, delegated by the objective in Eq 2, with consistent discretisation adopted for the latent distributions [ref]48.
It is worth noting that, since bits-back works more compatibly with ANS, bits-back ANS  is usually the first choice for models learned with the ELBO functional.
